title: Here’s what Boston meteorologists are saying the day after the historic blizzard
author: John Waller
bullets: Boston reported 17.1 inches of snowfall on February 23, setting a new daily record for this date.
The blizzard raises Boston's seasonal snowfall to over 60 inches, a mark not seen since the 2015 winter.
T.F. Green International Airport in Warwick, RI saw 37.9 inches of snow, potentially setting a state record.

title: 4 maps predicting totals from Wednesday morning’s snowfall
author: John Waller
bullets: A clipper system will pass north of Boston, bringing a lighter snowfall on Wednesday.
The National Weather Service predicts snow turning to rain in lower elevations by mid-morning.
Forecasts expect 1-3 inches of snow for most areas, with up to 3 inches in higher elevations.

title: Dozens of volunteers canvas Boston for homeless people outside as blizzard bears down on the city
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Pine Street Inn teams canvassed Boston with supplies, offering rides to shelters during a blizzard that dumped over 16 inches of snow.
The outreach teams reported seeing 50 people outside overnight on Sunday, fewer than usual as more opted for shelter.
Pine Street Inn's shelters, with a 585-bed capacity, held over 660 people using extra cots and mats during the blizzard.

title: 50 percent of departing Boston Logan Airport flights canceled Tuesday
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Over 50% of flights departing Boston Logan Airport were canceled Tuesday due to a nor'easter affecting New England.
Amtrak suspended services between Boston and New York on Monday, with hopes to resume by Tuesday's morning commute.
Passengers are advised to check flights as weather impacts resumption of operations at Logan and Amtrak's service decisions.

title: To trade or not to trade? Bruins must make their call with Viktor Arvidsson.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins must decide whether to trade Viktor Arvidsson before the March 6, 2026 NHL trade deadline.
Arvidsson has scored 14 goals and 28 points in 45 games, contributing significantly to Boston's playoff race.
Bruins are balancing the option of trading Arvidsson for future assets against maintaining playoff momentum.

title: These Mass. schools are closed on Tuesday, Feb. 24.
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Massive snowstorm forces widespread school closures in Massachusetts on Feb. 24, affecting districts across the state.
Over 30 inches of snow prompts districts like Boston, Cambridge, and Worcester to announce closures for February 24.
Some districts such as Athol-Royalston and Littleton delayed opening due to the snowstorm's impact on infrastructure.

title: AJ Brown recalls ‘critical’ Mike Vrabel moments that changed hatred to respect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: AJ Brown recounts early dislike for coach Mike Vrabel but now respects him after critical coaching moments.
Brown shared on a podcast that Vrabel's tough coaching pushed him to improve during his rookie year.
Speculation grows on Brown as a trade candidate for the Patriots, who need receiver improvements.

title: US women’s hockey declines invite to State of the Union, men’s hockey also invited in viral Trump phone call
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The U.S. women's hockey team declined an invitation to attend the State of the Union, citing scheduling conflicts.
The U.S. women's team defeated Canada 2-1 to win gold at the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milan.
The U.S. men's hockey team, also invited, celebrated their gold medal win against Canada in an overtime victory.

title: Patriots cut running back Antonio Gibson to save cap space
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots released Antonio Gibson to free over $3 million in cap space, incurring $1 million in dead money.
Gibson, recovering from a torn ACL, was a key third-down back and kick returner in 22 games for New England.
New England's running back depth includes Rhamondre Stevenson, TreVeyon Henderson, Terrell Jennings, Elijah Mitchell, and Lan Larison.

title: Yes, this storm is officially a blizzard. Here’s what meteorologists want you to know.
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Meteorologists declared a blizzard in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, impacting areas including Boston and Providence, on Monday.
Blizzard conditions require visibility of 1/4 mile or less for three hours, with winds of at least 35 mph.
The National Weather Service issued a warning with potential 75 mph gusts, advising against travel due to whiteout conditions.
